column1: Kingston upon Hull
column2: usually abbreviated to Hull
column3: is a port city and unitary authority in the East Riding of Yorkshire
column4: northeastern England. It lies upon the River Hull at its confluence with the Humber Estuary
column5: 25 miles (40 km) inland from the North Sea
column6: 50 miles (80 km) east of Leeds
column7: 34 miles (55 km) south-east of York and 54 miles (87 km) north-east of Sheffield. With a population of 259
column9: Hull is the fourth-largest city in Yorkshire and the Humber.

column1: The town of Wyke on Hull was founded late in the 12th century by the monks of Meaux Abbey as a port from which to export their wool.
Renamed Kings-town upon Hull in 1299
column2: Hull had been a market town
column3: military supply port
column4: trading hub
column5: fishing and whaling centre and industrial metropolis.

column1: Hull was an early theatre of battle in the English Civil Wars. Its 18th-century Member of Parliament
column2: William Wilberforce
column3: took a prominent part in the abolition of the slave trade in Britain.After suffering heavy damage in the Second World War (the "Hull Blitz")
column4: Hull weathered a period of post-industrial decline
column5: gaining unfavourable results on measures of social deprivation
column6: education and policing. In the early 21st century spending boom before the late 2000s recession the city saw large amounts of new retail
column7: commercial
column8: housing and public service construction spending.

column1: Tourist attractions include The Hull People's Memorial
column2: the historic Old Town and Museum Quarter
column3: Hull Marina and The Deep aquarium. Sports teams include EFL League One football club Hull City and rugby league clubs Hull F.C. & Hull Kingston Rovers and non-league football club Hull United.

column1: The University of Hull was founded in 1927 and now enrols more than 16
column2: 000 students. Hull was the 2017 UK City of Culture and in the same year the city's Ferens Art Gallery hosted the prestigious Turner Prize.

column1: == History ==
Kingston upon Hull stands on the north bank of the Humber Estuary at the mouth of its tributary
column2: the River Hull. The valley of the River Hull has been inhabited since the early Neolithic period but there is little evidence of a substantial settlement in the area of the present city. The area was attractive to people because it gave access to a prosperous hinterland and navigable rivers but the site was poor
column3: being remote
column4: low-lying and with no fresh water. It was originally an outlying part of the hamlet of Myton
column5: named Wyke. The name is thought to originate either from a Scandinavian word Vik meaning inlet or from the Saxon Wic meaning dwelling place or refuge.The River Hull was a good haven for shipping
column6: whose trade included the export of wool from Meaux Abbey
column7: which owned Myton. In 1293 the town of Wyke was acquired from the abbey by King Edward I
column8: who on 1 April 1299 granted it a royal charter that renamed the settlement King's town upon Hull or Kingston upon Hull. The charter is preserved in the archives of the Guildhall.In 1440
column9: a further charter incorporated the town and instituted local government consisting of a mayor
column10: a sheriff and twelve aldermen.In his Guide to Hull (1817)
column11: J. C. Craggs provides a colourful background to Edward's acquisition and naming of the town. He writes that the King and a hunting party started a hare which "led them along the delightful banks of the River Hull to the hamlet of Wyke … [Edward]
column12: charmed with the scene before him
column13: viewed with delight the advantageous situation of this hitherto neglected and obscure corner. He foresaw it might become subservient both to render the kingdom more secure against foreign invasion
column14: and at the same time greatly to enforce its commerce". Pursuant to these thoughts
column16: Edward purchased the land from the Abbot of Meaux
column17: had a manor hall built for himself
column18: issued proclamations encouraging development within the town
column19: and bestowed upon it the royal appellation
column20: King's Town.The port served as a base for Edward I during the First War of Scottish Independence and later developed into the foremost port on the east coast of England. It prospered by exporting wool and woollen cloth
column21: and importing wine and timber. Hull also established a flourishing commerce with the Baltic ports as part of the Hanseatic League.From its medieval beginnings
column22: Hull's main trading links were with Scotland and northern Europe. Scandinavia
column23: the Baltic and the Low Countries were all key trading areas for Hull's merchants. In addition

column1: Sir William de la Pole was the town's first mayor. A prosperous merchant
column2: de la Pole founded a family that became prominent in government. Another successful son of a Hull trading family was bishop John Alcock
column3: who founded Jesus College
column4: Cambridge and was a patron of the grammar school in Hull. The increase in trade after the discovery of the Americas and the town's maritime connections are thought to have played a part in the introduction of a virulent strain of syphilis through Hull and on into Europe from the New World.

column1: The town prospered during the 16th and early 17th centuries
column2: and Hull's affluence at this time is preserved in the form of several well-maintained buildings from the period
column3: including Wilberforce House
column4: now a museum documenting the life of William Wilberforce.During the English Civil War
column5: Hull became strategically important because of the large arsenal located there. Very early in the war
column6: on 11 January 1642
column7: the king named the Earl of Newcastle governor of Hull while Parliament nominated Sir John Hotham and asked his son
column8: Captain John Hotham
column9: to secure the town at once. Sir John Hotham and Hull corporation declared support for Parliament and denied Charles I entry into the town. Charles I responded to these events by besieging the town. This siege helped precipitate open conflict between the forces of Parliament and those of the Royalists.

column1: Whaling played a major role in the town's fortunes until the mid-19th century.As sail power gave way to steam
column2: Hull's trading links extended throughout the world. Docks were opened to serve the frozen meat trade of Australia
column3: New Zealand and South America. Hull was also the centre of a thriving inland and coastal trading network
column4: serving the whole of the United Kingdom.Throughout the second half of the 19th century and leading up to the First World War
column5: the Port of Hull played a major role in the emigration of Northern European settlers to the New World
column6: with thousands of emigrants sailing to the city and stopping for administrative purposes before travelling on to Liverpool and then North America.Parallel to this growth in passenger shipping was the emergence of the Wilson Line of Hull (which had been founded in 1825 by Thomas Wilson). By the early 20th century
column7: the company had grown – largely through its monopolisation of North Sea passenger routes and later mergers and acquisitions – to be the largest privately owned shipping company in the world
column8: with over 100 ships sailing to different parts of the globe. The Wilson Line was sold to the Ellerman Lines – which itself was owned by Hull-born magnate (and the richest man in Britain at the time) Sir John Ellerman.Hull's prosperity peaked in the decades just before the First World War; it was during this time
column10: that city status was granted. After the decline of the whaling industry
column11: emphasis shifted to deep-sea trawling until the Anglo-Icelandic Cod War of 1975–1976. The conditions set at the end of this dispute initiated Hull's economic decline.Many of the suburban areas on the western side of Hull were built in the 1930s
column12: particularly Willerby Road and Anlaby Park
column13: as well as most of Willerby itself. This was part of the biggest British housing boom of the 20th century (possibly ever).

column1: === Hull Blitz ===
The city's port and industrial facilities
column2: coupled with its proximity to mainland Europe and ease of location being on a major estuary
column3: led to extremely widespread damage by bombing raids during the Second World War; much of the city centre was destroyed. Hull had 95% of its houses damaged or destroyed
column4: making it the most severely bombed British city or town in terms of number of damaged or destroyed buildings
column5: apart from London
column6: during the Second World War. More than 1
column7: 200 people died in air raids on the city and some 3
column8: 000 others were injured.The worst of the bombing occurred in 1941. Little was known about this destruction by the rest of the country at the time
column9: since most of the radio and newspaper reports did not reveal Hull by name but referred to it as "a North-East town" or "a northern coastal town". Most of the city centre was rebuilt in the years following the war. As recently as 2006 researchers found documents in the local archives that suggested a non-exploded wartime bomb might be buried beneath a major new redevelopment
column10: the Boom

column1: === City of Culture ===
In 2017 Hull was awarded the title of 'City of Culture' by the department for Digital
column2: Culture
column3: Media and Sport. Within the city there was a series of festivals which occurred in public spaces to promote the city and its newly given title. At the start of the year there was a huge firework display attracting a crowd of 25
column4: 000. Furthermore
column5: development to the infrastructure of Hull occurred with new pavements being developed across the city-centre. The celebration featured a performance from Lil Nas X at The Deep aquarium.

column1: == Governance ==
Following the Local Government Act 1888
column2: Hull became a county borough
column3: a local government district independent of the East Riding of Yorkshire. This district was dissolved under the Local Government Act 1972
column4: on 1 April 1974 when it became a non-metropolitan district of the newly created shire county of Humberside. Humberside (and its county council) was abolished on 1 April 1996 and Hull was made a unitary authority area.The single-tier local authority of the city is now Hull City Council (officially Kingston upon Hull City Council)
column5: headquartered in the Guildhall in the city centre. The council was designated as the UK's worst performing authority in both 2004 and 2005
column6: but in 2006 was rated as a two star 'improving adequate' council and in 2007 it retained its two stars with an 'improving well' status. In the 2008 corporate performance assessment the city retained its "improving well" status but was upgraded to a three star rating.The Liberal Democrats won overall control of the City Council in the 2007 local elections
column7: ending several years in which no single party had a majority. They retained control in the 2008 local elections by an increased majority and in the 2010 local elections. Following the UK's local elections of 2011
column8: the Labour Party gained control of the council
column9: increasing their majority in the 2012 and retained this following the 2014 local elections. They increased their majority by one in the 2015 local elections
column10: but lost it in the

column1: 2016 local elections. In the 2018 local elections all of the council was up for election following boundary changes that reduced the number of seats by 2. Labour retained control of the council but with a much reduced majority
column2: while in the 2019 local elections there was no change to the make-up of the council.The city returned three members of parliament to the House of Commons and at the last general election
column4: elected three Labour MPs: Emma Hardy
column5: Diana Johnson and Karl Turner.William Wilberforce is the most celebrated of Hull's former MPs. He was a native of the city and the member for Hull from 1780 to 1784 when he was elected as an Independent member for Yorkshire.

column1: Hull is the only city and forms the major urban area in the official government-defined Hull and Humber Ports City Region.
== Geography ==

Kingston upon Hull is on the northern bank of the Humber Estuary. The city centre is west of the River Hull and close to the Humber. The city is built upon alluvial and glacial deposits which overlie chalk rocks but the underlying chalk has no influence on the topography. The land within the city is generally very flat and is only 2 to 4 metres (6.5 to 13 ft) above sea level. Because of the relative flatness of the site there are few physical constraints upon building and many open areas are the subject of pressures to build.The parishes of Drypool
column2: Marfleet
column3: Sculcoates
column4: and most of Sutton parish
column5: were absorbed within the borough of Hull in the 19th and 20th centuries. Much of their area has been built over
column6: and socially and economically they have long been inseparable from the city. Only Sutton retained a recognisable village centre in the late 20th century
column7: but on the south and east the advancing suburbs had already reached it. The four villages were
column8: nevertheless
column9: distinct communities
column10: of a largely rural character
column11: until their absorption in the borough—Drypool and Sculcoates in 1837
column13: and Sutton in 1929. The current boundaries of the city are tightly drawn and exclude many of the metropolitan area's nearby villages
column14: of which Cottingham is the largest. The city is surrounded by the rural East Riding of Yorkshire.

column1: Some areas of Hull lie on reclaimed land at or below sea level. The Hull Tidal Surge Barrier is at the point where the River Hull joins the Humber Estuary and is lowered at times when unusually high tides are expected. It is used between 8 and 12 times per year and protects the homes of approximately 10
column2: 000 people from flooding. Due to its low level
column3: Hull is expected to be at increasing levels of risk from flooding due to global warming.Many areas of Hull were flooded during the June 2007 United Kingdom floods
column4: with 8
column5: 600 homes and 1
column6: 300 businesses affected.Historically
column7: Hull has been affected by tidal and storm flooding from the Humber; the last serious floods were in the 1950s
column9: 1954 and the winter of 1959.At around 00:56 GMT on 27 February 2008
column10: Hull was 30 miles (48 km) north of the epicentre of an earthquake measuring 5.3 on the Richter Scale which lasted for nearly 10 seconds. This was an unusually large earthquake for this part of the world. Another notable quake occurred early in the morning of 10 June 2018.

column1: === Climate ===
Located in Northern England
column2: Hull has a temperate maritime climate which is dominated by the passage of mid-latitude depressions. The weather is very changeable from day to day and the warming influence of the Gulf Stream makes the region mild for its latitude. Locally
column3: the area is sunnier than most areas this far north in the British Isles
column4: and also considerably drier
column5: due to the rain shadowing effect of the Pennines. It is somewhat warmer than west coast areas at a similar latitude such as Liverpool in summer due to stronger shielding from maritime air but also colder in winter and North Sea breezes keep the city cooler than inland areas during summer. It is also one of the most northerly areas where the July average maximum temperature exceeds 21.5 °C (70.7 °F)
column6: although this appears to be very localised around the city itself. Flooding in June 2007 caused significant damage to areas of the city. Droughts and heatwaves also occur such as in 2003
column7: 2006 and recently in 2018.The absolute maximum temperature recorded is 34.4 °C (93.9 °F)
column8: set in August 1990. Typically
column9: the warmest day should reach 28.8 °C (83.8 °F)
column10: though slightly over 10 days should achieve a temperature of 25.1 °C (77.2 °F) or more in an "average" year. All averages refer to the 1981–2010 period.

column1: The absolute minimum temperature is −11.1 °C (12.0 °F)
column2: recorded during January 1982. Winters are generally mild for the latitude with snow only occurring a couple of times a year on average and mostly only staying for a day or 2 before melting. However
column3: it is frequently cloudy and the North Sea winds make it feel colder than it actually is. An average of 32.5 nights should report an air frost. Heavy snowfalls do occasionally occur such as in 2010.

column1: On 23 November 1981
column2: during the record-breaking nationwide tornado outbreak
column3: Hull was struck by two tornadoes. The first
column4: rated as a very weak F0/T0 tornado
column5: touched down in the Port of Hull shortly before 13:30 local time. This was followed several minutes later by a much stronger F1/T2 tornado
column6: which passed through and caused damage to residential buildings across the north-eastern suburbs of Hull.

column1: == Demography ==
According to the 2001 UK census
column2: Hull had a population of 243
column3: 589 living in 104
column4: 288 households. The population density was 34.1 per hectare. Of the total number of homes 47.85% were rented compared with a national figure of 31.38% rented. The population had declined by 7.5% since the 1991 UK census
column5: and has been officially estimated as 256
column6: 200 in July 2006.In 2001
column7: approximately 53
column8: 000 people were aged under 16
column10: 000 were aged 16–74
column12: 000 aged 75 and over. Of the total population 97.7% were white and the largest minority ethnic group was of 749 people who considered themselves to be ethnically Chinese. There were 3% of people living in Hull who were born outside the United Kingdom. In 2006
column13: the largest minority ethnic grouping was Iraqi Kurds who were estimated at 3
column14: 000. Most of these people were placed in the city by the Home Office while their applications for asylum were being processed. In 2001
column15: the city was 71.7% Christian. A further 18% of the population indicated they were of no religion while 8.4% did not specify any religious affiliation.

column1: Also in 2001
column2: the city had a high proportion
column4: of people of working age who were unemployed
column5: ranking 354th out of 376 local and unitary authorities within England and Wales. The distance travelled to work was less than 3 miles (4.8 km) for 64
column6: 578 out of 95
column7: 957 employed people. A further 18
column8: 031 travelled between 3.1 and 6.2 miles (5 and 10 km) to their place of employment. The number of people using public transport to get to work was 12
column9: 915 while the number travelling by car was 53
column10: 443.Men in the University ward had the fourth lowest life expectancy at birth
column12: of any ward in England and Wales in 2016.

column1: == Economy ==
The economy of Hull was built on trading and seafaring
column2: firstly whaling and later seafishing. Merchant's houses such as Blaydes House and some warehouses survive in the Old Town
column3: where trade was centred on the River Hull
column4: later shifting to the Humber docks. Another major industry was oilseed crushing. Although the fishing industry declined in the 1970s due to the Cod Wars
column5: the city remains a busy port
column6: handling 13 million tonnes of cargo per year. The port operations run by Associated British Ports and other companies in the port employ 5
column7: 000 people. A further 18
column8: 000 are employed as a direct result of the port's activities.

column1: The port area of the city has diversified to compensate for the decline in fishing by the introduction of Roll-on Roll-off ferry services to the continent of Europe. These ferries now handle over a million passengers each year.

Hull has exploited the leisure industry by creating Hull Marina from the old Humber and Railway docks in the centre of the city. It opened in 1983 and has 270 berths for yachts and small sailing craft.
Industry in the city is focused on the chemical and health care sectors. Several well-known British companies
column2: including BP
column3: Smith & Nephew and Reckitt Benckiser
column4: have facilities in Hull.

column1: The health care sector is further enhanced by the research facilities provided by the University of Hull through the Institute of Woundcare and the Hull York Medical School partnerships. In recent years
column2: with the decline of fishing and heavy industry
column3: the retail sector
column4: tourism
column5: the arts and further and higher education sectors have played an increasingly prominent role in the process of economic regeneration and raising the profile of the city. In 2009 it was estimated that businesses in Hull deliver an annual turnover of almost £8 billion
column6: and over 5 million annual visitors contribute almost £210 million to Hull's economy.

column1: === Retail ===
As the biggest settlement in the East Riding of Yorkshire and the local transport hub
column2: Hull is a natural focus for retail shoppers. Major department stores in Hull include Debenhams
column3: House of Fraser
column4: and until its collapse British Home Stores (BHS). The city centre has three main shopping centres
column5: St Stephen's
column6: Princes Quay
column7: and the Prospect Centre. There are also a number of "retail parks"
column8: and suburban shopping centres including St Andrews Quay retail park on the Humber bank and Kingswood retail park (Kingswood).

column1: Hull also has many shopping streets
column2: both inside and outside the city centre.  The main non-city-centre shopping streets are Hessle Road
column3: Holderness Road
column4: Chanterlands Avenue
column5: Beverley Road
column6: Princes Avenue
column7: and Newland Avenue. Additionally
column8: two covered shopping arcades remain in the town centre: Hepworth Arcade
column9: and Paragon Arcade.

column1: The St Stephen's shopping centre development on Ferensway adjacent to Hull Paragon Interchange is a 560
column2: 000-square-foot (52
column3: 000 m2) scheme
column4: that opened in 2007. It is anchored by a large 24-hour Tesco Extra superstore and provides many shop units
column5: food outlets
column6: a hotel
column7: and a 7 screen cinema. The St Stephens development is in direct competition with the Princes Quay Shopping Centre (1991)
column8: which was built on stilts over the closed Prince's Dock
column9: and houses a variety of chain stores and food outlets. It was originally built with four retail floors
column10: known as "decks"
column11: with the uppermost deck housing a Vue cinema since December 2007. Since the opening of St Stephens
column12: shopping patterns within the city centre have shifted away from the vicinity around Princes Quay
column13: resulting in reduced footfall.The Prospect Centre on Prospect Street is a smaller
column14: older shopping centre which benefits from large footfall and is home to a range of chain stores
column15: banks and fashion retailers. It contains branches of Boots
column21: and Hull's main post office. Outside the city centre at Bransholme
column22: the North Point Shopping Centre (Bransholme Shopping Centre) contains a similar range of popular chain stores and budget-oriented retailers including Boyes and Heron Foods.

column1: The city's branch of Woolworth's on King Edward Street closed in 2008
as did the branch of T J Hughes on the site of the former C&A store on Ferensway in August 2011
column2: following the parent companies' bankruptcies.There are a number of budget and discount retailers including four branches of Boyes
column3: Primark
column4: Peacocks. Hull has a selection of supermarkets
column5: including several branches of Tesco
column6: Sainsbury's
column7: Morrisons
column8: the Co-operative and budget food stores.

column1: The electrical retailer Comet Group was founded in the city as Comet Battery Stores Limited in 1933; the company's first superstore was opened in Hull in 1968. Other retailers such as Heron Foods
column2: and Jacksons also began their operations in Hull.

column1: === Development
In addition to the St Stephen's retail project
column2: a number of other commercial
column3: office and services developments were planned or took place during the first decade of the 21st century. One high-profile project was the £165 million Humber Quays development
column4: built near to the Humber Estuary
column5: which gained World Trade Centre status as the World Trade Centre Hull & Humber. Phase 1 of the project includes two office buildings and 51 new apartments. A second phase is expected to include a new 200-bedroom 4-star hotel
column6: a restaurant
column7: and more high-quality office space. The 50-stall indoor Edwardian Trinity Market
column8: a grade II listed building
column9: and Hepworth's Arcade were modernised and renovated in the late 2000s. The city centre railway station
column10: and adjacent bus terminal were also redeveloped

column1: Several large-scale developments also planned
column2: including a £100 million residential development on east bank of the River Hull
column3: called the Boom
column4: which would include over 600 luxury riverside apartments
column5: shops
column6: boutiques
column7: bistro cafés
column8: a 120-bed luxury hotel
column9: and health and education facilities. Also planned and not built was the Quay West extension to the Princes Quay shopping centre
column10: that was cancelled in 2010.The late 2000s recession halted many of the building development projects. Additionally

column12: Yorkshire Forward was abolished.The 'Boom' development was to be linked to the city centre by a new swing footbridge
column14: across the River Hull. The bridge was officially opened in June 2013.An investment of £14.5 million by Network Rail was used to enhance the capacity of the port freight railway line
column16: (completed 2008); the project was intended to increase its capacity from 10 trains per day to 22.

column1: == Culture ==

Hull has several museums of national importance. The city has a theatrical tradition with some famous actors and writers having been born and lived in Hull. The city's arts and heritage have played a role in attracting visitors and encouraging tourism in recent efforts at regeneration. Hull has a diverse range of architecture and this is complemented by parks and squares and a number of statues and modern sculptures. The city has inspired author Val Wood who has set many of her best-selling novels in the city. The Wilberforce Lecture and award of the Wilberforce Medallion
column2: which has taken place annually since 1995
column3: celebrates the historic role of Hull and William Wilberforce in combating the abuse of human rights.In April 2013 Hull put forward a bid to be the UK City of Culture in 2017
column4: reaching the shortlist of four in June 2013 along with Dundee
column5: Leicester and Swansea Bay. On 20 November 2013
column6: Maria Miller
column7: the Culture Secretary
column8: announced that Hull had won the award to become the UK City of Culture 2017.Monopoly have released a version focusing on Hull
column9: with attractions such as the Deep and St Stephens included.

column1: === Museums ===
==== Museums-quarter ====

The Museums Quarter is a development on the High Street in the heart of the Old Town. It combines four museums around a leisure garden. The work cost £5.1 million and was carried out from 1998 to 2003
column2: being formally opened by the Duke of Gloucester.The Museums are Wilberforce House
column3: the birthplace of William Wilberforce (1759–1833)
column4: the British politician
column5: abolitionist and social reformer; the Arctic Corsair
column6: a deep-sea trawler that was converted to a museum ship in 1999
column7: on the adjacent River Hull; the Hull and East Riding Museum
column8: showing the archaeology and history of the region; and the Streetlife Museum of Transport
column9: which includes a sizeable collection of vintage cars
column10: preserved public transport vehicles and horse-drawn carriages.

column1: ==== Others ====
Other museums include the Hull Maritime Museum in Victoria Square
column2: the Spurn Lightship
column3: and The Deep
column4: a public aquarium.

column1: === Art galleries ===
The civic art gallery is the Ferens Art Gallery on Queen Victoria Square
column2: a Grade II listed building. It is named after Thomas Ferens who provided the funds for it. Other galleries include the three-storey Humber Street Gallery
column3: in the former Fruit Market building which was opened in 2017 as part of Hull City of Culture. This now includes the "Dead Bod"
column4: a graffito originally painted on the Alexandria Dock
column5: which became a local landmark. There are other smaller exhibition spaces.

column1: === Visual culture and sculpture ===
Marine painter John Ward (1798–1849) was born
column2: worked and died in Hull and a leading ship artist of his day.

column1: Artist and Royal Academician Professor David Remfry (born 1942) grew up in Hull and studied at the Hull College of Art (now part of Lincoln University) from 1959 to 1964. His tutor
column2: Gerald T Harding
column3: trained at the Royal College of Art
column4: London and was awarded the Abbey Minor Travelling Scholarship in 1957 by the British School in Rome. Remfry has had two solo exhibitions at the Ferens Art Gallery in 1975 and 2005.

column1: Hull has a number of historical statues such as the Wilberforce Memorial in Queen's Gardens and the gilded King William III statue on Market Place (known locally as "King Billy"). There is a statue of Hull-born Amy Johnson in Prospect Street. In recent years a number of modern art sculptures and heritage trails have been installed around Hull. These include a figure looking out to the Humber called 'Voyage' which has a twin in Iceland. In July 2011
column2: this artwork was reported stolen. There is a shark sculpture outside The Deep and a fountain and installation called 'Tower of Light' outside Britannia House on the corner of Spring Bank.

column1: The Seven Seas Fish Trail marks Hull's fishing heritage
column2: leading its followers through old and new sections of the city
column3: following a wide variety of sealife engraved in the pavement. Running along Spring Bank there is also an elephant trail
column4: with stone pavers carved by a local artist to the designs of members of the community. This trail commemorates the Victorian Zoological Gardens and the route taken daily by the elephant as it walked from its house down Spring Bank to the zoo and back
column5: stopping for gingerbread at a shop on the way. The animals are further represented on the Albany Street 'Home Zone' a project involving local residents and resulting in sculptures of a hippo ('Water Horse') at the bottom of Albany Street; an elephant balancing on its trunk on an island in the middle; and two bears climbing poles and reaching out to each other to form an open archway across the entrance to Albany Street from Spring Bank. Other sculptural details of animals along the street represent the participation of street residents
column6: either through workshops with artists and makers
column7: or through independent work of their own.In 2010 a public art event in Hull city centre entitled Larkin with Toads displayed 40 individually decorated giant toad models as the centrepiece of the Larkin 25 festival. Most of these sculptures have since been sold off for charity and transported to their new owners. Visitors to Hull's Paragon Interchange are now greeted by the new statue of Philip Larkin unveiled on 2 December 2010.In 2019 a series of blue plaques appeared around Hull as part of the Alternative Heritage project.

column1: The art project was designed to celebrate the little known and quirky facts that make Hull the city it is. A variety of tongue in cheek and humorous blue plaques appeared over night celebrating everything from Chip Spice to The Beautiful South. New plaques continue to appear on a regular basis and their content has occasionally divided opinion in the city.
=== Theatres ===
The city has two main theatres. Hull New Theatre
column2: which opened in 1939
column3: with a £16 million refurbishment in 2016–17
column4: is the largest venue which features musicals
column5: opera
column6: ballet
column7: drama
column8: children's shows and pantomime.

column1: The Hull Truck Theatre is a smaller independent theatre
column2: established in 1971

column1: that regularly features plays
column2: notably those written by John Godber.

column1: Since April 2009
column2: the Hull Truck Theatre has had a new £14.5 million
column3: 440 seat venue in the St Stephen's Hull development. This replaced the former home of the Hull Truck Theatre on Spring Street
column4: a complex of buildings demolished in 2011. The playwright Alan Plater was brought up in Hull and was associated with Hull Truck Theatre.

column1: Hull has produced several veteran stage and TV actors. Sir Tom Courtenay
column2: Ian Carmichael and Maureen Lipman were born and brought up in Hull. Younger actors Reece Shearsmith
column3: Debra Stephenson
column4: Liam Gerrard and Liam Garrigan were also born in Hull.

column2: there were 29 cinemas in Hull but most of these have now closed. The first purpose-built cinema was the Prince's Hall in George Street which was opened in 1910 by Hull's theatre magnate
column3: William Morton. It was subsequently renamed the Curzon.

column1: On 25 July 2018
column2: a new 3
column3: 000 seat arena was opened to the public in the centre of the city. It was officially opened on 20 August 2018
column4: with a Van Morrison concert.

column1: === Poetry ===

Hull has attracted the attention of poets to the extent that the Australian author Peter Porter has described it as "the most poetic city in England".Philip Larkin set many of his poems in Hull; these include "The Whitsun Weddings"
column2: "Toads"
column3: and "Here". Scottish-born Douglas Dunn's Terry Street
column4: a portrait of working-class Hull life
column5: is one of the outstanding poetry collections of the 1970s.

column1: Dunn forged close associations with such Hull poets as Peter Didsbury and Sean O'Brien; the works of some of these writers appear in the 1982 Bloodaxe anthology A Rumoured City
column2: a work that Dunn edited. Andrew Motion
column3: past Poet Laureate
column4: lectured at the University of Hull between 1976 and 1981
column5: and Roger McGough studied there. Both poets spoke at the Humber Mouth Festival in 2010. Contemporary poets associated with Hull are Maggie Hannan
column6: David Wheatley
column7: and Caitriona O'Reilly.17th-century metaphysical poet and parliamentarian Andrew Marvell was born nearby
column8: grew up and was educated in the city. There is a statue in his honour in the Market Square (Trinity Square)
column9: set against the backdrop of his alma mater Hull Grammar School.

column1: === Music ===
==== Classical ====
In the field of classical music
column2: Hull is home to Sinfonia UK Collective (formerly Hull Sinfonietta
column3: founded in 2004)
column4: a national and international touring group that serves Hull and its surrounding regions in its role as Ensemble in Residence at University of Hull
column5: and also the Hull Philharmonic Orchestra
column6: one of the oldest amateur orchestras in the country. and formerly The Hull Philharmonic Youth Orchestra
column7: established in 1952

column1: the Hull Choral Union
column2: the Hull Bach Choir – which specialises in the performance of 17th- and 18th-century choral music - the Hull Male Voice Choir
column3: the Arterian Singers and two Gilbert & Sullivan Societies: the Dagger Lane Operatic Society and the Hull Savoyards are also based in Hull. There are two brass bands
column4: the East Yorkshire Motor Services Band
column5: who are the current North of England Area Brass Band Champions
column6: and East Riding of Yorkshire Band who are the 2014 North of England Regional Champions within their section.Hull City Hall annually plays host to major British and European symphony Orchestras with its 'International Masters' orchestral concert season. During the 2009–10 season visiting orchestras included the St Petersburg Symphony Orchestra and the Czech National Symphony Orchestra. Internationally renowned touring pop
column7: rock
column8: and comedy acts also regularly play the City Hall.In September 2013 a five-year partnership with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra was announced by the City Council.

column1: ==== Rock
column2: pop and folk ====

column1: On the popular music scene
column2: in the 1960s
column3: Mick Ronson of the Hull band Rats worked closely with David Bowie and was heavily involved in production of the album The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars. Ronson later went on to record with Lou Reed
column4: Bob Dylan
column5: Morrissey and the Wildhearts. There is a Mick Ronson Memorial Stage in Queen's Gardens in Hull. The 1960s were also notable for the revival of English folk music
column6: of which the Hull-based quartet
column7: the Watersons were prominent exponents. The Who performed and recorded a concert
column8: at the Hull City Hall
column9: on 15 February 1970.In the 1980s
column10: Hull groups such as the Red Guitars
column11: the Housemartins and Everything but the Girl found mainstream success
column12: followed by Kingmaker in the 1990s. Paul Heaton
column13: former member of the Housemartins went on to front the Beautiful South. Another former member of the Housemartins
column15: now performs as Fatboy Slim. In 1982
column17: Stuart Matthewman and Paul Spencer Denman formed the group Sade. In 1984
column18: the singer Helen Adu signed to CBS Records and the group released the album Diamond Life. The album had sales of four million copies. Vocalist and actor Roland Gift
column19: who formed the Fine Young Cannibals
column20: grew up in Hull.The pioneering industrial band Throbbing Gristle formed in Hull; Genesis P-Orridge (Neil Megson) attended Hull University between 1968 and 1969
column21: where he met Cosey Fanni Tutti (Christine Newby)
column22: who was born in the city
column23: and first became part of the Hull performance art group COUM Transmissions in 1970.The record label Pork Recordings started in Hull in the mid-1990s
column24: and has released music by Fila Brazillia.The New Adelphi is a popular local venue for alternative live music in the city
column25: and has achieved notability outside Hull
column26: having hosted such bands as the Stone Roses
column30: while the Springhead caters to a variety of bands and has been recognised nationally as a 'Live Music Pub of the Year'.In the 2000s
column31: Hull indie rock band The Paddingtons saw mainstream success with two UK Top 40 singles in 2005
column32: later reforming in 2014 and performing at the Humber Street Sesh with notable bands such as Sulu Babylon and Street Parade.

column1: In the 1990s
column2: the duo Scarlet from Hull had two Top 40 hits with "Independent Love Song" and "I Wanna Be Free (To Be With Him)" in 1995.The Humber Street Sesh night has released four DIY compilations featuring the cream of Hull's live music scene
column3: and there are currently a few labels emerging in the city
column4: including Purple Worm Records based at Hull College
column5: with bands such as The Blackbirds showing a promising future.

column1: === Nightlife
column2: bars and pubs ===

column1: The drinking culture in Hull city centre tends towards late bars
column2: while the wine bars and pubs around Hull University and its accommodation area are popular with students. In particular
column3: the areas around Newland Avenue and Prince's Avenue have seen a rapid expansion in continental-style bars and cafes encouraged by the redesign of the street layout.

column1: Hull has two gay bars (Propaganda and Fuel)
column2: and nightclubs
column3: such as Atik in the city centre. There is also an alternative club called Spiders
column4: with music ranging from rock to indie.

column1: The main drinking area in the city centre is the Old Town. One pub has Hull's smallest window (The George Hotel). England's civil war was said to be started in a pub situated in the Old Town.
=== Festivals ===
The Humber Mouth literature festival is an annual event and the 2012 season featured artists such as John Cooper Clarke
column2: Kevin MacNeil and Miriam Margolyes.

column1: The annual Hull Jazz Festival takes place around the Marina area for a week at the beginning of August.From 2008 Hull has also held its Freedom Festival
column2: an annual free arts and live music event that celebrates freedom in all its forms. Performers have included Pixie Lott
column3: JLS and Martha Reeves and The Vandellas
column4: Public Service Broadcasting and The 1975 as well as featuring a torchlight procession
column5: local bands like The Talks and Happy Endings from Fruit Trade Music label and a Ziggy Stardust photo exhibition including photos of the late-Hull-born Mick Ronson who worked with David Bowie. Former United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan was awarded the Wilberforce Medallion at the 2017 festival.Early October sees the arrival of Hull Fair which is one of Europe's largest travelling funfairs and takes place on land adjacent to the KCOM Stadium.The city's Pride in Hull festival is one of the largest free-to-attend LGBT+ Pride events in the UK
column6: attracting in excess of 50
column7: 000 attendees. Headline performers have included Adore Delano
column8: Louise Redknapp
column9: Marc Almond
column10: Nadine Coyle of Girls Aloud

column1: The Hull Global Food Festival held its third annual event in the city's Queen Victoria Square for three days – 4–6 September 2009. According to officials
column2: the event in 2007 attracted 125
column3: 000 visitors and brought some £5 million in revenue to the area.

column1: In 2007 the Hull Metalfest began in the Welly Club
column2: it featured major label bands from the United States
column3: Canada and Italy
column4: as well as the UK.

column1: The first Hull Comedy Festival
column2: which included performers such as Stewart Lee and Russell Howard was held in 2007.In 2010
column3: Hull marked the 25th anniversary of the death of the poet Philip Larkin with the Larkin 25 Festival. This included the popular Larkin with Toads public art event. The 40 Larkin toads were displayed around Hull and later sold off in a charity auction. A charity appeal raised funds to cast a life-size bronze statue of Philip Larkin
column4: to a design by Martin Jennings
column5: at Hull Paragon Interchange. The statue was unveiled at a ceremony attended by the Lord Mayor of Hull on 2 December 2010
column6: the 25th anniversary of Larkin's death. It bears an inscription drawn from the first line of Larkin's poem
column7: 'The Whitsun Weddings'.In 2013
column8: from 29 April to 5 May
column9: Hull Fashion Week took place with various events happening in venues in and around Hull's City centre. It finished with a finale on 5 May at Hull Paragon Interchange
column10: when recently reformed pop group Atomic Kitten appeared in a celebrity fashion show.On 3 August 2013
column11: the second Humber Street Sesh Festival took place celebrating local music talent and arts
column12: with several stages showcasing bands and artists from the Fruit Trade Music Label
column13: Humber Street Sesh and Purple Worm Records.In 2018
column14: the 16th Pride in Hull festival saw attendees take part in the annual celebration of LGBT+ culture. Headline performers included Adore Delano
column16: SuRie and Bright Light Bright Light.

column2: Hull Pride had acts such as Alaska 5000
column3: Social Beings and Step. Kerry Katona was due to perform at Fuel nightclub
column4: but cancelled the performance.

column1: == Churches ==
Unlike many other English cities
column2: Hull has no cathedral; but since 13 May 2017
column3: it has a Minster
column4: Hull Minster. This was formerly known as Holy Trinity Church
column5: and dates to about 1300
column6: Hull is in the Anglican Diocese of York and has a Suffragan bishop.Hull forms part of the Southern Vicariate of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Middlesbrough and included among Hull's Catholic churches is St Charles Borromeo
column7: the oldest post-Reformation Roman Catholic church in the city.There are several seamen's missions and churches in Hull. The Mission to Seafarers has a centre at West King George Dock and the St Nikolaj Danish Seamen's Church is located in Osborne Street.

column1: == Parks and green spaces ==
Hull has a large number of parks and green spaces. These include East Park
column2: Pearson Park
column3: Pickering Park
column4: Peter Pan Park (Costello Playing fields)
column5: and West Park. West Park is home to Hull's KCOM Stadium. Pearson Park contains a lake and a 'Victorian Conservatory' housing birds and reptiles. East Park has a large boating lake and a collection of birds and animals. East Park and Pearson Park are registered Grade II listed sites by Historic England.

column1: The city centre has the large Queen's Gardens parkland at its heart. This was originally built as formal ornamental gardens used to fill in the former Queen's Dock. It is now a more flexible grassed and landscaped area used for concerts and festivals
column2: but retains a large ornamental flower circus and fountain at its western end.

column1: The streets of Hull's suburban areas also lined with large numbers of trees
column2: particularly the Avenues area around Princes Avenue
column3: and Boulevard to the west. Many of the old trees in the Avenues district have been felled in recent years with the stumps carved into a variety of 'living sculptures'. Other green areas include the University area and parts of Beverley Road to the north.

column1: West Hull has a district known as 'Botanic'. This recalls the short-lived Botanic Garden that once existed on the site now occupied by Hymers College. Elephants once lived nearby in the former Zoological Gardens on Spring Bank and were paraded in the local streets. The land has since been redeveloped. There was also a former Botanic Garden between Hessle Road and the Anlaby Road commemorated by Linnaeus Street.
== Media ==
Hull's only local daily newspaper is the longstanding Hull Daily Mail
column2: whose circulation area covers much of the East Riding of Yorkshire too.  A free paper
column3: The Hull Advertiser
column4: used to be issued weekly by the same publisher.

column1: The city was once served by three competing daily newspapers
column2: all operating from the Whitefriargate area Eastern Morning News
column3: Hull News and Hull and East Yorkshire Times. On 17 April 1930 the last edition of Evening News was published after the paper was taken over by its longstanding rival the Hull Daily Mail.

column1: Local listings and what's-on guides include Tenfoot City Magazine and Sandman Magazine (combined into single volume covering all of England
column2: print version then made defunct in favour of online site). The BBC has its Yorkshire and Lincolnshire regional headquarters at Queen's Gardens
column3: from which the regional news programme Look North is broadcast.

column1: Radio services broadcasting from the city are community radio stations
column2: Hull Kingston Radio
column3: 106.9 West Hull FM (formerly WHCR FM) and Hospital radio station Kingstown Radio. The BBC's regional station BBC Radio Humberside is also based in Hull and broadcasts to East Yorkshire & Northern Lincolnshire. Commercial stations for the city Viking FM and Greatest Hits Radio Yorkshire (formerly KCFM broadcast from outside of Hull and are now part of a national network like Capital FM Yorkshire which has a base over 60 miles (100 km) away in Leeds.

column1: The Hull University Union's student radio station Jam 1575
column2: stopped broadcasting on MW.On 24 November 2013 a RSL (Restricted Service Licence) was given to new station "Hull Community Radio" broadcasting on 87.9 FM.

column1: == Sport ==
Sports in the city include professional football
column2: rugby league
column3: golf
column4: darts
column5: athletics and watersports.The city's professional football club
column6: Hull City A.F.C.
column7: play in League One
column8: the third tier of the English football league system
column9: after relegation from the Championship in the 2019–20 season. The team play at the KCOM Stadium. There are also two non-league clubs based in the city
column10: Hall Road Rangers
column13: who play at Hull College Craven Park. Both teams play in the Northern Counties East Division One.

column1: Hull is also a rugby league hub
column2: in the Super League competition is Hull FC
column3: alongside the city's football club Hull City A.F.C.
column4: play at the KCOM Stadium. Also in Super League are Hull Kingston Rovers
column5: who play at KCOM Craven Park Stadium in East Hull
column6: following promotion from the Championship in 2017.

column1: There are also several lower league teams in the city
column2: such as East Hull
column3: West Hull
column4: Hull Dockers and Hull Isberg
column5: who all play in the National Conference League. Rugby union is catered for by Hull Ionians who play at Brantingham Park. and Hull RUFC who are based in the city.The city has two athletics clubs based at the Costello Stadium in the west of the city – Kingston upon Hull Athletics Club and Hull Achilies Athletics Club.

column1: Hull Cycle Speedway Club is at the Hessle raceway near the Humber bridge. The side race in the sports Northern league and won both the league titles in 2008. Other cycling clubs also operate throughout the city including Hull Thursday
column2: the area's road racing group.

column1: Hull Arena
column2: is an ice rink and concert venue
column3: which is home to the Hull Pirates ice hockey team who play in the National Ice Hockey League National League following reorganisation for the 2019–20 season. It is also home to the Kingston Kestrels ice sledge hockey team. In August 2010
column4: Hull Daily Mail reported that Hull Stingrays was facing closure
column5: following a financial crisis. The club was subsequently saved from closure following a takeover by Coventry Blaze. But on 24 June 2015
column6: the club announced on its official website that it has been placed into liquidation.The Hull Hornets American football existed from 2005 until 2011. The club
column7: which acquired full member status in the British American Football League on 5 November 2006
column8: played in the BAFL Division 2 Central league for 5 years. The Humber Warhawks formed in 2013 are now Hull's American football team. Greyhound racing returned to the city on 25 October 2007 when The Boulevard stadium re-opened as a venue for the sport.

column1: In mid-2006 Hull was home to the professional wrestling company One Pro Wrestling
column2: which held the Devils Due event on 27 July in the Gemtec Arena. From 16 May 2008
column3: Hull gained its own homegrown wrestling company based at the Eastmount Recreation Centre—New Generation Wrestling—that have featured the likes of El Ligero
column4: Kris Travis
column5: Martin Kirby and Alex Shane.Hull Lacrosse Club was formed in 2008 and currently plays in the Premier 3 division of the North of England Men's Lacrosse Association.The city played host to the Clipper Round the World Yacht Race
column6: a tough 35
column7: 000 miles (56
column8: 000 km) race around the globe
column9: for the 2009–10 race which started on 13 September 2009 and finished on 17 July 2010. The locally named yacht
column10: Hull and Humber
column12: achieved second place in the 2007–2008 race.The city hosted The British Open Squash Championships at the KC Stadium in 2013 and 2014
column13: before moving to the adjacent Airco Arena in 2015
column14: as part of a three-year deal.

column1: == Transport ==
The main road into and out of Hull is the M62 motorway/A63 road
column2: one of the main east–west routes in Northern England. It provides a link to the cities of Leeds
column3: Manchester and Liverpool
column4: as well as the rest of the country via the UK motorway network. The motorway itself ends some distance from the city; the rest of the route is along the A63 dual carriageway. This east–west route forms a small part of the European road route E20.Hull is close to the Humber Bridge
column5: which provides road links to destinations south of the Humber. It was built between 1972 and 1981
column6: and at the time was the longest single-span suspension bridge in the world. It is now eighth on the list.

column1: Before the bridge was built
column2: those wishing to cross the Humber had to either take a Humber Ferry or travel inland as far as Goole.Bus services are provided by Go Ahead North East company East Yorkshire (previously known as EYMS) and Stagecoach in Hull which cover the city's central
column3: suburban and industrial areas. To provide greater travel flexibility
column4: bus users can obtain a 'Hull Card' which can be used on services run by either operator.Hull Paragon Interchange
column5: opened on 16 September 2007

column1: is the city's transport hub
column2: combining the main bus and rail termini in an integrated complex. It is expected to have 24
column3: 000 people passing through the complex each day.

column1: There are services that run to certain other parts of the UK. These include through expresses to London
column2: up to seven per day provided by Hull Trains and one a day by London North Eastern Railway. Other long-distance rail services are provided by TransPennine Express serving Leeds and Manchester. Northern Trains operates regular local stopping trains to Beverley
column3: Brough and Goole
column4: and the coastal towns of Bridlington and Scarborough
column5: along with services to Selby
column6: York
column7: Doncaster and Sheffield.

column1: P&O Ferries provide daily overnight ferry services from King George Dock in Hull to Zeebrugge and Rotterdam.

Services to Rotterdam are worked by ferries MS Pride of Rotterdam and MS Pride of Hull. Services to Zeebrugge are worked by ferries MS Pride of Bruges and MS Pride of York (previously named MS Norsea). Both Pride of Rotterdam and Pride of Hull are too wide to pass through the lock at Hull. Associated British Ports built a new terminal at Hull to accommodate the passengers using these two ferries. The Rotterdam Terminal at the Port of Hull
column2: was built at a cost of £14

column1: The nearest airport is Humberside Airport
column2: 20 miles (32 km) away in Lincolnshire
column3: which provides a few charter flights but also has high-frequency flights to Amsterdam with KLM and Aberdeen with Eastern Airways each day. Doncaster Sheffield Airport in South Yorkshire is 48 miles (77 km) from Hull city centre and provides a wider choice of charter flights as well as a number of low-cost flights to certain European destinations. The nearest airport with intercontinental flights is Leeds Bradford Airport is 70 miles (110 km) away.Road transport in Hull suffers from delays caused both by the many bridges over the navigable River Hull
column4: which bisects the city and which can cause disruption at busy times
column5: and from the remaining three railway level crossings in the city. The level-crossing problem was greatly relieved during the 1960s by the closure of the Hornsea and Withernsea branch lines
column6: by the transfer of all goods traffic to the high-level line that circles the city
column7: and by the construction of two major road bridges on Hessle Road (1962) and Anlaby Road (1964).

column1: According to the 2001 census data cycling in the city is well above the national average of 2%
column2: with a 12% share of the travel to work traffic. A report by the University of East London in 2011 ranked Hull as the fourth-best cycling city in the United Kingdom.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Telephone system ===
Hull is the only city in the UK with its own independent telephone network company
column2: KCOM
column3: formerly KC and Kingston Communications
column4: a subsidiary of KCOM Group. Its distinctive cream telephone boxes can be seen across the city. KCOM produces its own 'White Pages' telephone directory for Hull and the wider KC area. Colour Pages is KCOM's business directory
column5: the counterpart to Yellow Pages. The company was formed in 1902 as a municipal department by the City Council and is an early example of municipal enterprise. It remains the only locally operated telephone company in the UK
column6: although it is now privatised. KCOM's Internet brands are Karoo Broadband (ISP serving Hull) and Eclipse (national ISP).

column1: Initially Hull City Council retained a 44.9 per cent interest in the company and used the proceeds from the sale of shares to fund the city's sports venue
column2: the KCOM Stadium
column3: among other things. On 24 May 2007 it sold its remaining stake in the company for over £107 million.KCOM (Kingston Communications) was one of the first telecoms operators in Europe to offer ADSL to business users
column4: and the first in the world to run an interactive television service using ADSL
column5: known as Kingston Interactive TV (KiT)
column6: which has since been discontinued due to financial problems. In the last decade
column7: the KCOM Group has expanded beyond Hull and diversified its service portfolio to become a nationwide provider of telephone
column8: television
column9: and Internet access services
column10: having close to 180
column11: 000 customers projected for 2007. After its ambitious programme of expansion
column12: KCOM has struggled in recent years and now has partnerships with other telecommunications firms such as BT who are contracted to manage its national infrastructure. Telephone House

column1: In October 2019
column2: Hull became the first UK city to have full fibre broadband available for all residents.

column1: === Hydraulic power ===
The first public hydraulic power network
column2: supplying many companies
column3: was constructed in Hull. The Hull Hydraulic Power Company began operation in 1877
column4: with Edward B. Ellington as its engineer and the main pumping station (now a Grade II listed building) in Catherine Street. Ellington was involved in most British networks
column5: including those in London
column6: Liverpool
column7: Birmingham
column8: Manchester and Glasgow
column9: but the advent of electrical power combined with wartime damage meant the Hull company was wound up in 1947.

column1: === Public services ===
Policing in Kingston upon Hull is provided by Humberside Police. In October 2006 the force was named (jointly with Northamptonshire Police) as the worst-performing police force in the United Kingdom
column2: based on data released from the Home Office. However
column3: after a year of "major improvements"
column4: the Home Office list released in October 2007 shows the force rising several places (although still among the bottom six of 43 forces rated). Humberside Police received ratings of "good" or "fair" in most categories.HM Prison Hull is located in the city and is operated by HM Prison Service. It caters for up to 1
column5: 000 Category B/C adult male prisoners.Statutory emergency fire and rescue service is provided by the Humberside Fire and Rescue Service
column6: which has its headquarters near Hessle and five fire stations in Hull. This service was formed in 1974 following local government reorganisation from the amalgamation of the East Riding of Yorkshire County Fire Service
column7: Grimsby Borough Fire and Rescue Service
column8: Kingston Upon Hull City Fire Brigade and part of the Lincoln (Lindsey) Fire Brigade and a small part of the West Riding of Yorkshire County Fire and Rescue Service.Hull and East Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust provides healthcare from three sites
column9: Hull Royal Infirmary
column10: Castle Hill Hospital and
column12: Princess Royal Hospital and there are several private hospitals including ones run by BUPA and Nuffield Hospitals. The Yorkshire Ambulance Service provides emergency patient transport. NHS primary health care services are commissioned by the Hull Clinical Commissioning Group and are provided at several smaller clinics and general practitioner surgeries across the city. NHS Mental health services in Hull are provided by Humber NHS Foundation Trust. It runs a memory clinic in Coltman Street
column13: west Hull designed to help older people with early onset dementia.Waste management is co-ordinated by the local authority. The Waste Recycling Group is a company which works in partnership with the Hull City and East Riding of Yorkshire councils to deal with the waste produced by residents. The company plans to build an energy from waste plant at Salt End to deal with 240
column14: 000 tonnes of rubbish and put waste to a productive use by providing power for the equivalent of 20
column15: 000 houses. Hull's Distribution Network Operator for electricity is CE Electric UK (YEDL); there are no power stations in the city. Yorkshire Water manages Hull's drinking and waste water. Drinking water is provided by boreholes and aquifers in the East Riding of Yorkshire
column16: and it is abstracted from the River Hull at Tophill Low
column17: near Hutton Cranswick. Should either supply experience difficulty meeting demand
column18: water abstracted from the River Derwent at both Elvington and Loftsome Bridge can be moved to Hull via the Yorkshire water grid. There are many reservoirs in the area for storage of potable and non-potable water. Waste water and sewage has to be transported in a wholly pumped system because of the flat nature of the terrain to a sewage treatment works at Salt End. The treatment works is partly powered by both a wind turbine and a biogas CHP engine.

column1: == Education ==
=== Higher education ===
==== University of Hull ====
Kingston upon Hull is home to the University of Hull
column2: which was founded in 1927 and received its Royal Charter in 1954. It now has a total student population of around 20
column3: 000 across its main campuses in Hull and Scarborough. The main University campus is in North Hull
column4: on Cottingham Road. Notable alumni include former Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott
column5: the poet Philip Larkin
column6: social scientist Lord Anthony Giddens
column7: Woman's Hour presenter and writer Jenni Murray
column8: and the dramatist Anthony Minghella. The University of Hull is a partner in the new University Centre of the Grimsby Institute of Further and Higher Education (GIFE) being built in Grimsby
column9: North Lincolnshire.

column1: ==== Hull York Medical School ====

Hull York Medical School is a joint venture between the University of Hull and the University of York. It first admitted students in 2003 as a part of the British government's attempts to train more doctors.
==== University of Lincoln ====
The University of Lincoln grew out of the University of Humberside
column2: a former polytechnic based in Hull. In the 1990s the focus of the institution moved to nearby Lincoln and the administrative headquarters and management moved in 2001. The University of Lincoln has retained a campus in George Street in Hull city centre whilst Hull University purchased the adjacent University of Lincoln campus site on Cottingham Road.

column1: ==== Other institutions ====
The Hull School of Art
column2: founded in 1861
column3: is regarded nationally and internationally for its excellence as a specialist creative centre for higher education.The Northern Academy of Performing Arts and Northern Theatre School both provide education in musical theatre
column4: performance and dance.

column1: === Schools and colleges ===
Hull has over 100 local schools; of these
column2: Hull City Council supports 14 secondary and 71 primary schools. The highest achieving state school in Hull is Malet Lambert School

column1: Schools which are independent of the City Council include Hymers College and Hull Collegiate School. The latter
column2: which is run by the United Church Schools Trust
column3: was formed by the merging of Hull Grammar School and Hull High School. There is a further education college
column4: Hull College
column5: and two large sixth form colleges
column6: Wyke College and Wilberforce College. East Riding College operates a small adult education campus in the city
column7: and Endeavour Learning and Skills Centre is an adult education provision operated by Hull Training & Adult Education. Hull Trinity House Academy has been offering pre-sea training to prospective mariners since 1787.

column1: There are only two single-sex schools in Hull: Trinity House Academy
column2: which teaches only boys
column3: and Newland School for Girls.

column1: ==== Schools ratings ====
The city has had a poor examination success rate for many years and is often at the bottom of government GCSE league tables.
In 2007 the city moved off the bottom of these tables for pupils who achieve five A* to C grades
column2: including English and Maths
column3: at General Certificate of Secondary Education by just one place when it came 149th out of 150 local education authorities. However
column4: the improvement rate of 4.1 per cent
column5: from 25.9 per cent in 2006 to 30 per cent in summer 2007
column6: was among the best in the country.

column1: They returned to the bottom of the table in 2008 when 29.3 per cent achieved five A* to C grades which is well below the national average of 47.2 per cent. There are insufficient places in referral units for school children with special needs or challenging behaviour due to squeezed budgets and cuts to children's services.
== Dialect and accent ==

The local accent is quite distinctive and noticeably different from the rest of the East Riding; however it is still categorised among Yorkshire accents. The most notable feature of the accent is the strong I-mutation in words like goat
column2: which is [ˈɡəʊt] in standard English and [ˈɡoːt] across most of Yorkshire
column3: becomes [ˈɡɵːʔt̚ ] ("gert") in and around parts of Hull (cf. similar refined pronunciations in Leeds/York)
column4: although there is variation across areas and generations.

column1: In common with much of England (outside of the far north)
column2: another feature is dropping the H from the start of words
column3: for example Hull is more often pronounced 'Ull in the city. The vowel in "Hull" is pronounced the same way as in northern English
column4: however
column5: and not as the very short /ʊ/ that exists in Lincolnshire. Though the rhythm of the accent is more like that of northern Lincolnshire than that of the rural East Riding
column6: which is perhaps due to migration from Lincolnshire to the city during its industrial growth
column7: one feature that it does share with the surrounding rural area is that an /aɪ/ sound in the middle of a word often becomes an /ɑː/: for example
column8: "five" may sound like "fahve"
column9: "time" like "tahme".The SQUARE~NURSE merger is a feature of Hull's dialect. The vowel sound in words such as burnt
column10: nurse
column11: first is pronounced with an /ɛ/ sound
column12: as is also heard in Middlesbrough and in areas of Liverpool yet this sound is very uncommon in most of Yorkshire. The word pairs spur/spare and fur/fair illustrate this.

column1: The generational and/or geographic variation can be heard in word pairs like pork/poke or cork/coke
column2: or hall/hole
column3: which some people pronounce almost identically
column4: sounding to non-locals like they are using the second of the two variations – while others make more of a vocal distinction; anyone called "Paul" (for example) soon becomes aware of this (pall/pole).

column1: == Notable people ==

Most of the notable people associated with the city can be found in the People from Kingston upon Hull and People associated with the University of Hull categories.People from Hull are called "Hullensians" and the city has been the birthplace and home to many notable people. Amongst those of historic significance with a connection to Hull are former city MP William Wilberforce who was instrumental in the abolition of slavery
and Amy Johnson
column2: aviator who was the first woman to fly solo from England to Australia.Entertainers from the city include; Dorothy Mackaill
column3: 1950s singer David Whitfield
column4: sports commentator Tony Green
column5: actors Sir Tom Courtenay
column6: Ian Carmichael
column7: John Alderton and more recently Reece Shearsmith. and actress Maureen Lipman.

column1: Playwrights Richard Bean
column2: John Godber and Alan Plater have close connections with Hull.Musicians include: Paul Heaton of The Housemartins and The Beautiful South

column1: and guitarists Mick Ronson and Trevor Bolder
column2: who worked with David Bowie and more recently 2000s indie band The Paddingtons.The astrophysicist Edward Arthur Milne and logician John Venn both hailed from Hull. The poet Philip Larkin lived in Hull for 30 years and wrote much of his mature work in the city. Artist David Remfry RA studied at Hull College of Art before moving to London and New York.

column1: Chemist Professor George Gray
column2: who had a 45-year career at the university
column3: developed the first stable liquid crystals that became an immediate success for the screens of all sorts of electronic gadgets.

column1: Notable sportspeople include Ebenezer Cobb Morley (16 August 1831 – 20 November 1924) was an English sportsman and is regarded as the father of the Football Association and modern football. Clive Sullivan
column2: rugby league player
column3: who played for both of Hull's professional rugby league teams and was the first black Briton to captain any national representative team. The main A63 road into the city from the Humber Bridge is named after him (Clive Sullivan Way). Nick Barmby played for Tottenham Hotspur
column4: Middlesbrough
column5: Everton
column6: Liverpool
column7: and Leeds United before returning to play for his hometown club Hull City. He also won 23 England caps and played in the famous 5–1 victory over Germany in 2001. Another footballer is Dean Windass
column8: who had two spells with Hull City. On accepting a peerage
column9: Welsh-born Baron Prescott of Kingston-upon-Hull (former MP and Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott) took his title from his adopted home city of Hull.

column1: == Freedom of the City ==
The following people and military units have received the Freedom of the City of Kingston upon Hull.
=== Individuals ===
The Most Reverend Desmond Tutu : 2 July 1987.
Helen Suzman DBE: 2 July 1987.
Nelson Mandela OMP OM GCFR AC CC OJ GCStJ QC GCIH RSerafO NPk: 2 July 1987.
Rt Hon John Prescott: 1 August 1996.
Kevin McNamara KSG: 16 January 1997.
Jean Bishop – "Bee Lady": 23 November 2017.
Sir Thomas Courtenay: 18 January 2018.
Yvonne Blenkinsop: 15 November 2018.

The Royal Dragoon Guards

RAF Patrington: 16 May 1970.

RRH Staxton Wold: 3 March 1994.
150 (Yorkshire) Transport Regiment Royal Logistic Corps (Volunteers): 3 March 1994.
HMS Iron Duke
